user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_panic_std:
```c
_MHD_NORETURN static void
mhd_panic_std (void *cls,
               const char *file,
               unsigned int line,
               const char *reason)
{
  (void) cls; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  fprintf (stderr,
           _ ("Fatal error in GNU libmicrohttpd %s:%u: %s\n"),
           file,
           line,
           reason);
#else  /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */
  (void) file;   /* Mute compiler warning. */
  (void) line;   /* Mute compiler warning. */
  (void) reason; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#endif
  abort ();
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
  (void) file;   /* Mute compiler warning. */
  (void) line;   /* Mute compiler warning. */
  (void) reason; /* Mute compiler warning. */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario:
No violation in the shown fragment: the (void) casts are executed in the #else branch before abort() and therefore are reachable. A concrete violation scenario would be placing statements after a noreturn call (or after return), for example:

  abort();
  (void) file; /* unreachable — would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 */

or code following an unconditional return or an infinite loop with no exit — such code would be unreachable and thus violate Rule 2.1.
